awd_titl_txt: I/UCRC:  Proposal to Establish a Joint NSF I/UCR Center for  Particulate Systems and Surfactants
awd_abstract_narration:
In Phase II operation, the I/UCRC for Advanced Particulate Systems and Surfactants (CPaSS) intends to address challenges which fall under two broad categories: 1) characterization of particles and surfactants at nano and molecular scale, predictability in tuning their performance, and environmental and physiological compatibility, and 2) elucidation of understanding of structure-property-performance relationships in particulate/polymer/enzyme systems.  To address challenges in fabrication of particles and surfactant systems with tunable properties, development of predictive models to understand their behavior in industrially relevant environments is needed. This requires understanding the mechanisms by which particulate and surfactant systems of different properties behave under industrially relevant dynamic systems - a major theme of the center's Phase II research program.

Particulate and Surfactant Systems are vital to virtually every major industry including pharmaceuticals, detergents, cosmetics, liquid crystals, micro-electronics, advanced ceramics, petroleum and fuels, minerals, agriculture, biotechnology, photography, and paints and coatings.  Center research can contribute to efficient process development leading to more effective and less costly consumer products; tools and protocols to screen greenness of reagents and particles together - the platform for many industrial, household and healthcare products. CPaSS is committed to continue and increase the enrollment of women, underrepresented minorities and persons with disabilities during Phase II through stronger interactions with college and university programs that support recruitment of such students into the STEM fields.

por.por_cntn:
CPaSS Outcomes – Societal Impact:

Potential benefits of CPaSS research to society include more efficient process development leading to more competitive US manufacturing; less expensive consumer products; tools and protocols to screen greenness of reagents and particles together – the platform for many industrial, household, and healthcare products, thereby supporting the industry driven sustainability initiatives. In addition, a complimentary knowledgebase and research infrastructure along with the development of a diverse workforce are other outcomes of significant impact on industry and society at large. Although the Center researchers undertook several different projects at the Florida site, select projects are briefly described below as illustrative examples of the societal impact of the CPaSS research outcomes.

Antimicrobial coatings: The need for managing infectious diseases has never been greater. Some of these diseases, such as COVID are spread through airborne means, whereas others, such as  hospital-acquired infections - that cost billions of dollars every year to manage, are spread through surface contacts, in other words touching of surfaces. In this regard, the center researchers have developed a coating that decomposes the microbes into water and carbon dioxide gas, leaving no residue on the surface. This coating is in contrast to other methodologies that leave some residue, thereby reducing their efficacy over time. CPaSS coating formulation has been reported to result in a more than 50% reduction in infections in a healthcare facility environment.

Coatings for inhibiting corrosion:  Corrosion of structures, including pipelines, are estimated to cost over $300 billion per year in the United States alone. Among various corrosion mitigating methodologies for the transport of oil and utility water, specific formulations of the soap solution are used to reduce the corrosion. However, such coatings remain effective only if the formulation is continuously fed into the pipelines. Center researchers have determined the reasons for continuous feeding. Understanding the mechanism of corrosion inhibition promises to lead to formulations that are not only more cost effective, but also more environmentally friendly.

More reliable water sensors:  More accurate and reliable water contaminant sensors require narrowly sized gold nanoparticles. However, narrow size distribution can only be achieved in the batch production mode resulting in prohibitive production costs (in some cases more than $10K/g). CPaSS research team, in collaboration with an industry partner, has developed a continuous reactor that can produce narrowly sized gold particles at a fraction of the cost of batch reactors. The continuous reactor, when fully developed, will not only lead to the development of more accurate and reliable water sensors but will also enable other product developments such as in advanced materials that have yet to be realized due to the lack of availability of reasonably priced precise particles.

High solids slurry transport:  Transport of slurries via pipelines is critical to industrial production. However, pumping of slurries that contain particles that are not spherical in shape is highly costly. As a result, it is achieved only in the dilute suspension mode costing the industry billions of dollars per year in added production costs. Center researchers have used modeling and novel experimental techniques to understand the reasons for such observations. They have developed strategies that have already been implemented in commercial design software for slurry transport equipment resulting in substantial cost savings.

Natural oil coatings for crop protection: “Citrus Greening” is a deadly disease that has spread to such an extent that it is threatening even the existence of this industry in the United States. A formulation consisting of essential oils (or natural oils) was developed and successfully evaluated to reduce the rate of the spread of citrus greening in demonstration scale experiments. Essential oils or natural oils are known to function as natural biocides and are already used in the Food and Agriculture industry.

Longer lasting body implants:  Titanium and its alloys are favored as biomaterials for hard tissue replacements or implants due to their excellent mechanical strength and biocompatibility. In order to further enhance the longevity of body implants, the center research team has developed a novel three-dimensional chemical mechanical polishing process. This process enables the control of not only nano roughness, but also of generating biocompatibility enhancing specific nanostructures on the implant’s surfaces.

Better hand hygiene: Importance and awareness of proper hand washing have never been greater than in recent times. Although CDC prescribed hand washing technique reduces the number of infection causing microbes on hands, the only way to ensure complete disinfection is through the use of alcohol-based disinfectants. However, alcohol-based formulations need to be used in conjunction with suitable hand lotions. Otherwise, alcohol-based disinfectants can cause more harm than good. As an alternative, a particle-based formulation was developed and successfully evaluated in the center. This formulation was determined to remove almost four times more harmful bacteria from the skin than the conventionally used hand washing soap solutions.
